Award.AwardTitle: Gravitational redshifts of galaxy clusters and large-scale structure: New probes of modified gravity and dark matter
Award.AbstractNarration:
This program will develop a method of measuring the gravitational redshift effect (change in the frequency of light waves), which has become a new means of testing general relativity on on the scale of galaxies. There is also a plan to validate this method with numerical simulations. Broader impacts of the work include training of undergraduate and graduate students, and a postdoctoral researcher. With a collaborative team including computer science and graphics students at Carnegie Mellon, a computer game for public outreach will be developed based on cosmological structure formation.

Analytic theory and large scale realistic cosmological simulations will be employed to make predictions for gravitational redshifts of galaxies in various environments. Optimal statistical estimators will be formulated to best constrain the large-scale gravitational potential. These estimators will be applied to the simulated data to carry out tests and to make predictions, which will be applied to existing galaxy catalogs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit:

 

In 1960, two Physicists, one on the roof of the Harvard Physics Laboratory, and one in the basement carried out a major test of General Relativity (GR), Einstein's theory of gravity. Robert Pound and Glen Rebka were looking for evidence of a gravitational redshift of light. GR predicts that photons climbing up out of the Earth's gravitational field will lose energy and therefore increase in wavelength. The measurement became one of the four experimental pillars establishing the validity of GR on Earth and Solar System scales.  At the present day, we once again find ourselves in need of tests of our theories of gravity, but this time on much larger scales. The Universe is accelerating in its expansion, (research awarded the 2011 Nobel Prize). However, a simple accounting of its contents leads to the expectation that it should be decelerating. There are two leading possibilities to explain this. Either a previously unknown substance with negative pressure (``Dark Energy'') causes it to accelerate, or that our theory of gravity, GR, somehow breaks down when we approach cosmological scales. In order to tell these possibilities apart we therefore need to extend our tests of gravity to these scales. Measuring gravitational redshifts of entire galaxies offers a new way to do this. Our project has been working in this new area for the last four years, making the first detailed theoretical predictions as well as the first observational measurements.

 

 

The Universe on scales of hundreds of millions of light years is a web of galaxies and dark matter distributed in enormous clusters and superclusters. We have used supercomputing resources to carry out detailed simulations of the Universe, starting from the Big Bang and ending up with maps such as that shown in Figure 1. The various effects of Einsteins GR on the observational properties of galaxies are also predicted by our simulations. For example the gravitational redshift is shown by contours in Figure 1, and galaxies will have different values depending on how deeply they lie in the "gravitational potential wells" caused by dark matter. We have used these and other simulations to predict how these GR effects can be measured from observed galaxy data. We have made the first predictions of many effects, such as the "beaming" effect of light caused by relativity when galaxies move a significant fraction of the speed of light, the effects of gas dynamics and star formation on gravitational redshifts, and the effects of structure inside galaxies.

 

With the age of survey Cosmology, we are now able to access galaxy data for large volumes of the Universe. We used the largest current survey, the Sloan Digital Sky/Survey Baryon Oscillation Spectroscopic Survey (SDSS/BOSS), which contains 1.5 million galaxies, to make the first measurement of gravitational redshifts due to the large-scale structure of the Universe. Our measurement extended to scales of 50 million light years, and is consistent with Einstein's General Relativity - we find no evidence for deviations or modifications to our current theory of gravity.  We also made measurements on galaxy and galaxy cluster scales, using integral field spectroscopy data from the SDSS survey to look at gravitational redshifts inside galaxies. We created a special software data pipeline (see Figure 3) which increased precision over the standard data treatment by a factor of ten.  In this case we made the first significant constraints on the redshifts, showing that dark matter must be a subdominant component at the centers of galaxies, and again that GR works on thise scales.

 

Broader impacts:

 

A major outreach project has been the creation of a new way to teach how gravity works in the cosmos: "Galaxy formation", a video game which was written in collaboration with a team of undergraduate research students over 4 years.  The game aims to familiarize the players with how galaxies and structure forms in the Universe, as well as what dark matter is and what cosmologists study. The App uses a research-grade gravity simulation code to evolve a Universe of dark matter and shows where galaxies form. Apart from selecting initial conditions, the player can control the game by adjusting gravity where they want in the simulated Universe. The aim is to form as many galaxies as possible, or just to play with the Universe as a sandbox. The game runs on iOS devices, including iPhones and iPads. The game is currently under review at the Apple App store.  It is aimed to reach a wide audience in an engaging at entertaining way. The App will also be incorporated into our other outreach efforts. Over the life of the grant these have included interactive class activities related to "length scales in the cosmos" with middle school students, as well as public lectures at the Allegheny observatory and lecturing at the White House Science Frontiers Conference.
